data.question: What sequence is the short peptide ligand containing that was used in the study?
What metal was used for coordination in the folding and assembly process of the short peptide ligand?
What is the diameter of the larger helical nanochannel mentioned in the study?
What type of molecules were effectively encapsulated by the peptide-folded porous crystal?
data.answer: Anions, organic chiral molecules, and bio-oligomers

data.question: What was the overall yield of the tripeptide ligand 1 synthesis?
What was the yield of the colorless block crystals obtained from the crystallization process?
What happens to the BF4- counterions in the crystalline network upon soaking in a NaPF6 solution?
data.answer: They are easily exchanged with PF6- anions in a single-crystal-to-single-crystal fashion.

data.question: How was chiral recognition of 1,1'-bi-2-naphthol achieved?
data.answer: By soaking the single crystals in an ethanol solution of the racemic compound.

data.question: What was the enantiomeric excess percentage for the R-form of 1,1'-bi-2-naphthol encapsulated in the crystal?
How was maltopentaose encapsulated within the large channel A?
data.answer: By soaking the single crystals in a methanol solution of maltopentaose.

data.question: What was the ligand/guest ratio for maltopentaose encapsulation?
Is the peptide-based crystalline material capable of molecular recognition of bio-oligomers?
data.answer: Yes, it is capable of molecular recognition of bio-oligomers.

data.question: The folding and assembly process was induced by copper(I) coordination.
The larger helical nanochannel has a diameter of exactly 2 nm.
The tripeptide ligand 1 showed conformational flexibility in solution.
The crystalline material is composed of in situ folded peptide helices.
The BF4- counterions in the crystalline network cannot be exchanged with other anions.
The crystalline material does not show chiral recognition for chiral molecules.
Maltopentaose encapsulation was successful in pure methanol but not in aqueous methanol.
The peptide-based crystalline material is not suitable for the structural elucidation of bio-oligomers.
